results.title: Immigration
results.brief_description:
How the USA has been populated during the last two centuries. For many reasons people left the Old World to try their luck in the Americas - all have found a home in the USA during the past 200 years.
No credits available.

results.title: Imagination 10
results.creator_credit: Morton Goldscholl, Champion Papers and Morton Goldscholl Design
results.brief_description: This film pays tribute to the railroad and its contribution to America; discusses the type of life and work of the people who run the passenger and freight trains. Shows the aesthetic appeal of steel and steam and the beauty of nature along the right of way and is almost an abstract painting seen from a parlour car window, a montage of people. The film was prepared in conjunction with the publishing of a monograph on a variety of papers used by the railroads.

results.title: Images pour Debussy
results.brief_description: Scenes of rivers, streams, waves, fields are used in this visual interpretation of four Debussy works: “En Bateau”, “Reflets Dans L’Eau”, and the first and second “Arabesques”. Pianist: Jacques Ferrier.

results.title: Images pour Bach
results.brief_description: A series of abstract shapes and patterns are shown in synchronisation with two Bach compositions - Overture from the Suite for Orchestra No 5 in F major and Invention No 14 in D major are rearranged in modern electronic fashion. Colour and shape recur and vary according to the themes and variations in the musical structure.

results.title: Images of the wild
results.creator_credit: Norman Lightfoot, Beryl Fox and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Robert Bateman, Canadian naturalist and international wildlife artist, is seen at work in his studio in Rockwood, Ontario, on location in northern Ontario and East Africa, and at the opening night of a show of his paintings in Hamilton. He talks about his approach to nature, that dominates his approach to painting.

results.title: Images for quartet
results.creator_credit: Robert Parker, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Looks at the professional and private lives of the four musicians in the Carl Pini String Quartet (Carl Pini, violin; Gordon Bennet, violin; John Godd, viola; Barbara Woolley, cello) to the music of Debussy and Mendelssohn, and Australian composers Richard Meale and Brian Buggy. Note: A short version of the film ‘String quartet’ made in 1972.

results.title: [Images en negatif]
results.brief_description: An example of the use of negative film material to produce dramatic impact in film. The director, Eugene Deslaw, is one of the pioneers of the avant-garde cinema and in this film he explores the possibilities of negative photography. The result is a poem of imagination and beauty. (Awards: Diploma of Honour: Venice Film Festival, 1956)

results.title: The Image of the city
results.creator_credit: Charles Eames, Ray Eames, Smithsonian Institute and Westinghouse Electric Corporation
results.brief_description: Based on the Eames exhibition ‘Photography and the City’ designed for the Smithsonian Institute. This documentary looks at the changing representation of cities based on the available technologies of the time. In the late nineteenth century photography not only provided popular views of distant monuments and foreign cities, but by rendering things and events objectively, became a valuable tool in the examination of social systems. At the turn of the century, photographers experimented with kites to capture aerial images of cities. Today [1969], specialists working in environmental fields are using a wide variety of photographic techniques to study and clarify urban problems. Tools such as multiband cameras, radar images , computer-generated graphics, satellite observations and thermograms are making available new information about our cities, their environment, and the influences upon them. Alex Funke, Parke Meek and David Olney involved in production, music by Gerald Fried.

results.title: The Image of empire: the early Roman Empire and the rise of christianity
results.creator_credit: Mary Hoskins, British Broadcasting Corporation and Open University
results.brief_description: How, in the absence of modern means of communication can a Roman Emperor project an image of himself and his rule? J. Ferguson discusses the various forms of imperial propaganda which included patriotic writing, the use of inscriptions, coinage, sculpture and public works.
